questions.question:
Question 1: A patient receiving anti-tubercular therapy has been recently diagnosed with gout. Which of 
the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

options.d: Most commonly involves the first MTP joint

questions.explanation:
In gout, the crystals are negatively birefringent on polarized light microscopy of the joint aspirate. Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals 
in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males. It usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Acute gout 
presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The 
metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint. Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features: • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid Antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide and ethambutol cause hyperuricemia by inhibiting uric 
acid excretion in the kidney. Monosodium urate crystals as seen on polarized light microscopy: 477 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: An elderly man presented to the OPD with painful swelling of his left big toe. Synovial fluid 
examination showed negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. What are these crystals 
made of?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation and polarised microscopy showing negatively birefringent 
needle-shaped crystals point towards a diagnosis of gout. In gout, the negatively birefringent 
needle-shaped crystals are due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals. Monosodium urate crystals in gout: Option A: Calcium apatite crystals can accumulate in areas of tissue damage, hypercalcemia, or 
hyperparathyroid states. Option C: Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals 
that are seen in pseudogout. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals seen in pseudogout: 478 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Ammonium urate crystals can cause urinary bladder stones which are radiolucent but 
may develop a calcific coating making it visible on X-rays.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following synovial fluid crystals cannot be identified using polarized light 
microscopy?
questions.explanation: Calcium apatite crystals cannot be identified using polarized light microscopy. Polarized light microscopy can identify crystals such as: • Monosodium urate • Calcium pyrophosphate • Calcium oxalate

questions.question:
Question 4: 473 
Sold by @itachibot A patient has a history of multiple episodes of painful swelling of ankles and big toes which is 
relieved with NSAIDs. You would avoid all of the following drugs in her except:
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of multiple painful swelling of ankles and toes that responded to NSAIDs is 
suggestive of gout. High-dose salicylates (>3g/day) do not precipitate gout. Although high-dose salicylates inhibit both the secretion and reabsorption of urate, the inhibition 
of reabsorption is more than the inhibition of secretion, and therefore the net effect is uricosuric. On the other hand, low-dose salicylates (<2 to 3g/day) are associated with uric acid retention. 
They inhibit renal tubular secretion of uric acid resulting in hyperuricemia and may precipitate 
gout. Aspirin is not used to treat acute attacks of gout due to its uric acid retention property. However, 
low-dose aspirin used for cardiovascular prophylaxis need not be discontinued during the 
treatment of a gout flare. 479 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with chronic gout now presented to the emergency room after sustaining trauma to 
his left foot. Identify the abnormality in his X-ray given below.
questions.explanation:
The given X-ray of a patient with chronic gout shows Martel's sign. Martel's sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion, refers to the punched-out lytic lesion 
and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous 
gout. Option A: Podagra is the inflammation of the base of the great toe (metatarsophalangeal joint) 
during flares of gout. It is not a radiological sign. Option C: Chopart's fracture is a fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. Option D: March fracture is fracture neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal. X-ray showing Martel's sign:

questions.question:
Question 6: A 52-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of severe joint pain in his big toe 
with history of multiple similar episodes in the past. An ultrasound of the first 
metatarsophalangeal joint was performed. What is the characteristic finding depicted in the 
image given below? 474 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The characteristic finding depicted in the given ultrasound image of a patient with chronic gout is 
the double contour sign. Double contour sign is characterized by an echogenic line on the outer surface of the joint 
cartilage, due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals on the surface of articular 
cartilage. It is seen in chronic gout. Option A: Double wall sign also known as Rigler's sign is an abdominal radiograph finding seen 
in pneumoperitoneum. Here both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible. 480 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Double density sign on chest X-ray PA view is seen due to left atrial enlargement. Here, 
the right border of the left atrium becomes laterally displaced and convex producing this 
appearance. Option D: Double barrel sign is a USG finding seen in common bile duct (CBD) obstruction 
causing dilatation of CBD and its lumen size becomes comparable to portal vein giving the 
appearance of a double-barrel. 481 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged man presented to the ER with severe pain and swelling as shown in the image 
below. He told that he had consumed 2 bottles of beer a few hours before. Which of the 
following drugs is not used in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Allopurinol is used in the management 
of chronic gout. Urate-lowering drugs such as allopurinol, probenecid, and lesinurad are not initiated during acute 
attacks. The treatment options for an acute attack of gout include: • NSAIDs: Indomethacin, naproxen, ibuprofen, and diclofenac are highly effective • Colchicine: It acts by inhibiting neutrophil migration and reduces inflammation. It is used orally 
and is most effective if given early in an attack. • Glucocorticoids: Systemic glucocorticoids may be used in polyarticular involvement. If the 
disease is limited to one joint, intraarticular triamcinolone may be given.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following drugs is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic gout in a 
50-year-old patient?
questions.explanation: Allopurinol is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic or recurrent gout. Hypouricemic drugs that can be used for definitive treatment of chronic gout include: • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors- allopurinol, febuxostat • Uricosuric agents- probenecid, lesinurad • Recombinant uricases- rasburicase and pegloticase

questions.question:
Question 9: A 58-year-old man with history of gout is now diagnosed with hypertension. Which of the 
following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
482 
Sold by @itachibot Losartan is the drug of choice for the management of hypertension in a patient with gout because 
of its uricosuric action. Thiazides (hydrochlorothiazide, metolazone) and loop diuretics (furosemide) cause reduced 
excretion of uric acid from the renal tubules and result in hyperuricemia. Therefore they are not 
preferred for management of hypertension in patients with gout.

questions.question: Question 10: Which joint is most commonly affected in calcium pyrophosphate disease?
questions.explanation:
The knee joint is most commonly affected in calcium pyrophosphate (CPPD) disease or 
pseudogout. Other sites include the wrist, shoulder, ankle, elbow, and hands. Acute CPPD arthropathy is commonly seen in the elderly and may be associated with conditions 
such as primary hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, and hemochromatosis. X- ray of the affected joint may reveal chondrocalcinosis, which represents calcium deposition in 
articular cartilage. Polarised light microscopy of the joint aspirate demonstrates positively 
birefringent rhomboid crystals, as shown below: 483 
Sold by @itachibot Sjogren's Syndrome and Scleroderma
